data.title: Copp's Hill Burying Ground
data.meta_description: Copp's Hill Burying Ground, Boston, Massachusetts
data.text:
Following document was transcribed by Bob Kipke, October 2002. This softcover book, 6" x 9", 32 pages, 6 B&W plates, was found and purchased in San Diego, California, October 2002.

This document was transcribed as closely as possible to remain true to format (including capitalization & punctuation), spelling, and page numbering. Due to the spelling conventions of a different era, "Spell Check" could not be used, and each page had to be checked manually. Also, please note the extensive use of hyphenation.

--- NOT FOR COMMERICAL USE---

HERE LYES THE MORTAL PART

of

(William Clark Esqr.)

An Eminent Merchant of this Town, and

An Honorable Counsellor for the Province;

Who Distinguished Himself as

A Faithful and Affectionate Friend

A Fair and generous Trader;

Loyal to his (Prince), Yet always

Zealous for the Freedom of his Countrey;

A Despiser of Sorry Persons and fiecle Actions,

An Enemy to Priestcraft and Enthusiasm

Ready to relieve and help the Wretched;

A Lover of good Men of Various Denominations

And a Reverent Worshipper of the (Deity)

MY NAME FROM THE PALMS OF HIS HANDS

ETERNITY WILL NOT ERASE;

IMPRESSED ON HIS HEART, IT REMAINS

IN MARKS OF INDELIBLE GRACE.

YES, I TO THE END SHALL ENDURE,

AS SURE AS THE EARNEST IS GIVEN,

MORE HP-Y, BUT NOT MORE SECURE,

THE GLORIFIED SPIRITS IN HEAVEN.

(MAJOR SAMUEL SHAW,)

third son of

Francis & Sarah, served as an

Officer in the Revolutionary War,

from its commencement to

its close.

On the 22d of Feb. 1784, he sailed

from New York in the Ship

Empress of China, for Canton, as

Supercargo & part owner;

this being the first vessel that

sailed from the U. States for

that place

he was appointed by Washington

Consul to China, which office he

held until his death in 1794
